user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_alloc_memory_:
```c
void *
MHD_connection_alloc_memory_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                              size_t size)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /* a short alias */
  struct MemoryPool *const pool = c->pool;     /* a short alias */
  size_t need_to_be_freed = 0; /**< The required amount of additional free memory */
  void *res;

  res = MHD_pool_try_alloc (pool,
                            size,
                            &need_to_be_freed);
  if (NULL != res)
    return res;

  if (MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (pool,
                                     c->write_buffer,
                                     c->write_buffer_size))
  {
    if (c->write_buffer_size - c->write_buffer_append_offset >=
        need_to_be_freed)
    {
      char *buf;
      const size_t new_buf_size = c->write_buffer_size - need_to_be_freed;
      buf = MHD_pool_reallocate (pool,
                                 c->write_buffer,
                                 c->write_buffer_size,
                                 new_buf_size);
      mhd_assert (c->write_buffer == buf);
      mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_append_offset <= new_buf_size);
      mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_send_offset <= new_buf_size);
      c->write_buffer_size = new_buf_size;
      c->write_buffer = buf;
    }
    else
      return NULL;
  }
  else if (MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (pool,
                                          c->read_buffer,
                                          c->read_buffer_size))
  {
    if (c->read_buffer_size - c->read_buffer_offset >= need_to_be_freed)
    {
      char *buf;
      const size_t new_buf_size = c->read_buffer_size - need_to_be_freed;
      buf = MHD_pool_reallocate (pool,
                                 c->read_buffer,
                                 c->read_buffer_size,
                                 new_buf_size);
      mhd_assert (c->read_buffer == buf);
      mhd_assert (c->read_buffer_offset <= new_buf_size);
      c->read_buffer_size = new_buf_size;
      c->read_buffer = buf;
    }
    else
      return NULL;
  }
  else
    return NULL;
  res = MHD_pool_allocate (pool, size, true);
  mhd_assert (NULL != res); /* It has been checked that pool has enough space */
  return res;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected all conditional branches and return points that determine whether the function falls through to the final allocation or returns early. These are the places where unreachable code is most likely to occur (mutually exclusive branches, early returns, and the final code path that assumes prior checks).

Other parts of the function do not need investigation for unreachable-code concerns: the initial aliasing declarations (struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; struct MemoryPool *const pool = c->pool; size_t need_to_be_freed = 0; void *res;) are simple initialisations and are reachable whenever the function is called. The call to MHD_pool_try_alloc and the assignment to need_to_be_freed are included only via the first selected fragment (the immediate return on non-NULL res); no other isolated statements present in the code are inherently unreachable. The individual mhd_assert() calls that appear inside the selected blocks are included within those blocks for inspection; there are no other standalone statements or labels outside these blocks that are syntactically unreachable and therefore do not require further investigation for MISRA Rule 2.1.
